issue.title: [BUG] address imminent removal of deprecated `sklearn` `_pprint`

labels.name: maintenance
labels.description: Continuous integration, unit testing & package distribution

repository.name: sktime
repository.description: A unified framework for machine learning with time series

issue.body:
**Describe the bug**

next release 1.2.0 of scikit-learn will move pprint function and sktime will produce an error.

check this commit: https://github.com/scikit-learn/scikit-learn/commit/c63e38add5d0baa345cc363460dc0d0e18c87903


**To Reproduce**

install scikit-learn 1.2.0dev


```python
pip install --pre --extra-index https://pypi.anaconda.org/scipy-wheels-nightly/simple scikit-learn
```

**Expected behavior**
<!--
A clear and concise description of what you expected to happen.
-->

**Additional context**
<!--
Add any other context about the problem here.
-->

**Versions**
<details>

<!--
Please run the following code snippet and paste the output here:
 
from sktime import show_versions; show_versions()
-->

</details>

<!-- Thanks for contributing! -->

body: More details about scikit-learn develop installation: https://scikit-learn.org/stable/developers/advanced_installation.html#installing-nightly-builds
Does PyPI support a `dev` environment? I see that sklearn uses `pypi.anaconda.org` which suggest a "clone" or self-hosted pypi server.

@lmmentel Yea I think your can host your own pypi server!

But I don’t think that’s needed. If the goal is to install the latest sktime with pip, those interested can install the main branch via GitHub the url with pip.

This should work since sktime does not have compiled extensions anymore. This article explains how to do it:

https://simonwillison.net/2022/Apr/24/pip-install-github/
I think that solves it @freddyaboulton, maybe we only need to update the docs on how to install the latest from `main` with pip to close this?

Other suggestion is use "--pre". Somethig like pycaret, to install latest version can use this command: pip install --pre pycaret.

Question: It is possible use "--pre" to latest version on github, and normal pip without "--pre" to latest stable version?

example: 
- sktime 0.13.0 --------> pip install sktime
- sktime 0.13.1-dev ---> pip install --pre sktime 

makes sense?
Using pre flag would require to publish a tagged Prerelease version to pypi, installing from main seems way simpler.

ups looks like I made a mistake...
installing from source is simple:
pip install https://github.com/alan-turing-institute/sktime/archive/refs/heads/main.zip

It's simple. Thank you all
So... should we do this, or is all fine as is?

Agree with @lmmentel 's suggestion. I think we can add a sentence here showing how to install from github via url and then close:

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/41651716/179847269-5b5c4a0c-d90b-4db4-811d-48b6f5bc6ecf.png)
ok, anyone want to add that sentence? 😄
